description: Use the format Author_Year_Taxa_Model_fw, where the last two characters (here, fw) are alphanumeric and random.

example: Merow, Cory and Maitner, Brian and Owens, Hannah and Kass, Jamie and Enquist, Brian and Guralnick, Rob
description: The names of those who created this model.
The names of the person(s) who own this model.

constrainedValues: CC; CC BY; CC BY-SA; CC BY-ND; CC BY-NC; CC BY-NC-SA; CC BY-NC-ND; other
example: CC; CC BY; CC BY-SA; CC BY-ND; CC BY-NC; CC BY-NC-SA; CC BY-NC-ND
description: The license under which this model has been produced.  See https://creativecommons.org/licenses/ for common options.
An email address for someone responsible for creating this model.

example: @article{maitner2017bien,title={The bien r package: A tool to access the Botanical Information and Ecology Network (BIEN) database},author={Maitner, Brian S and Boyle, Brad and Casler, Nathan and Condit, Rick and Donoghue, John and Dur{\'a}n, Sandra M and Guaderrama, Daniel and Hinchliff, Cody E and J{\o}rgensen, Peter M and Kraft, Nathan JB and others},journal={Methods in Ecology and Evolution}, year={2017},publisher={Wiley Online Library}}
description: A single bibtex format citation or vector of citations; User specified

example: All authors contributed equally to the production of these models.
description: User specified. Any information related to author/ownership or limits on use.
User specified; Any context for the models that didn't fit elsewhere
Digital Object Identifier for manuscripts related to the model
A character vector containing all of the units (typically taxon names) used in the model(s). Other phylogroups or operational taxonomic units are also acceptable.

constrainedValues: presence only; presence absence; abundance; occupancy; other
description: The type of records used in modeling. If multiple types are combined this can be a vector. For example some point process modeling frameworks combine presence only and presence absence data so this would be specified (in R) as c('presence only', 'presences absence').
If a temporal range of records was used, this is the earliest year used.  Absence or NA implies that there was no lower limit.
If a temporal range of records was used, this is the latest year used.  Absence or NA implies there is no upper boundary used.

Supply a vector of maximum values in JSON format for all predictors used in modeling (even if each predictor was not used for each species)

Type of range the study focuses on. Use 'potential' if describing suitable habitat that may be occupied or unoccupied. Use 'realized' when describing only locations that are occupied.
If an invasion study, what type of data is the model fitted with. If not an invasion study, set to NULL.

description: Rules for choosing feature classes if different than Maxent's defaults. See maxent manual.
Multiplier used for regularization via the LASSO penalty. Maxent's default is 1. See maxent manual

example: Chosen based on 5-fold cross validation on a grid of regularization multipliers from [0;10]
description: User specified rule to choose the regularization multiplier if different than Maxent's default. See maxent manual.
Maxent's convergence threshold for terminating the fitting algorithm. See maxent manual

User specified rule to account for sampling bias. The most common method is target group, although sampling bias models can be used. See maxent manual and @article{author = {Phillips, SJ and Dudik, M and Elith, J and Graham, CH and Lehmann, A and Leathwick, J and Ferrier, S},title = {{Sample selection bias and presence-only distribution models: implications for background and pseudo-absence data}},journal = {Ecological Applications},year = {2009},volume = {19},number = {1},pages = {181--197}}

Specify any relevant information useful for describing how sampling bias was modeled. This might include related taxa, in the case of a target group, or covariates (such as distance to road) used to model the bias.

For use with Maxent or point process models to account for sampling bias. See: Phillips, S., M. Dudik, J. Elith, C. Graham, A. Lehmann, J. Leathwick, and S. Ferrier. 2009. Sample selection bias and presence-only distribution models: implications for background and pseudo-absence data. Ecological Applications 19:181–197.
Describe the values of an offset used.

example: sampling bias model fit to target group of all proteas
description: Describe the method/rule used to generate an offset.

Proportion of prior probability set inside the expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

example: Based on proportion of presences correctly classified
description: Rule for setting proportion of prior probability set inside the expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Decay rate of prior probability outside expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Rule for setting decay rate of prior probability outside expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Skew defines asymmetry in the decay rate outside the expert boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Rule for setting skew, which defines asymmetry in the decay rate outside the expert boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Shift of decay relative to the expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.

Rule for setting shift of decay relative to the expert map boundary. See @article{author = {Merow, Cory  and Wilson, Adam M and Jetz, Walter},title = {{Integrating occurrence data and expert maps for improved species range predictions}},journal = {Global Ecology and Biogeography},year = {2017},volume = {26},number = {2},pages = {243--258}}.
